noun.description: A piece of evidence or information used in the detection of a crime or solving of a mystery.
examples: police officers are still searching for clues

noun.description: A verbal formula giving an indication as to what is to be inserted in a particular space in a crossword or other puzzle.

verb.description: Inform someone about a particular matter.
examples: Stella had clued her in about Peter

phrases: I don't have a clue what she's talking about, so I'm trusting her on this one.
I get the impression her daughter doesn't have a clue what she does.
They don't have a clue about psychological damage.
But he admits he doesn't have a clue what terms like world music and global music mean.
Other friends don't have a clue what the game's about.
origin: Late Middle English: variant of clew. The original sense was a ball of thread; hence one used to guide a person out of a labyrinth. clue (sense 1 of the noun) dates from the early 17th century.
